docs.lead_paragraph: IN "The Red Sox, the Bean and the Cod," Al Hirshberg, prominent sports writer for The Boston Post, has told the story of the Boston team from its purchase in 1933 by Tom Yawkey, a baseball bemused young millionaire, to that recent autumn day when a stunned Johnny Pesky saw too late the wild dash of Enos Slaughter toward home plate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Catcher DAVE VALLE and the Boston Red Sox agreed yesterday to a $1.2 million, one-year contract, a steep cut from the $2,366,667 million he made last season with the Seattle Mariners. Last season, Valle, a former Queens high school star, had the best offensive year of his career and was one of the best defensive catchers in the American League, but after becoming a free agent, those factors did not produce a lucrative contract. Valle, 33, hit .258 for the Mariners last season and had career highs in games caught (135), hits (109), doubles (19), home runs (13) and runs batted in (63).

headline.main: Valle Joins Red Sox But Takes Pay Cut

docs.lead_paragraph: This World Series will be the 10th for Boston, which won its first five Series appearances from 1903-1918, but has lost its last four, each in seven games, from 1946 to 1986. For Red Sox followers, each losing Series has an unhealed wound. By RAY CORIO 1946 -- Taking a 3-2 lead to St. Louis, the Red Sox lost Game 6, then let Game 7 get out of hand when Johnny Pesky kept the ball in his hand a mite too long on a relay from the outfield. Enos Slaughter never hesitated in sprinting from first to home for the decisive run. 1967 -- Jim Lonborg pitched a one-hitter and a three-hitter for Boston, but Bob Gibson had three complete-game victories for the Cardinals, including the Game 7 matchup with Lonborg. 1975 -- There seemed to be no stopping Boston after Carlton Fisk's dramatic home run in the 12th inning won Game 6 and evened the Series with Cincinnati. But the Big Red Machine erased a 3-0 deficit in Game 7 and hummed to victory. 1986 -- The Red Sox took a 2-0 lead over the Mets to Boston and blew it. They held a 3-2 lead in games and runs in Game 6, and blew it in the eighth, then built a 5-3 lead in the 10th and blew the game on a tricky grounder to Bill Buckner at first base. Game 7? They squandered a 3-0 lead and cursed the Bambino.
